text: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. That man was blameless and upright, fearing God and avoiding evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His possessions were seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and very many servants. This man was the greatest of all the people of the East.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sons used to go and make a feast in the house of each on his day, and they would send and call for their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the days of feasting had run their course, Job sent and sanctified them. He would rise up early in the morning, and he would offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all, because Job said: “It may be that my sons have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job would do always.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and the Adversary also came among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the Lord said to the Adversary, “From where have you come?”
Then the Adversary answered the Lord, saying, “From roaming on the earth, and from walking up and down on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to the Adversary, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and an upright man, who fears God, and avoids evil?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Adversary answered the Lord, saying, “Has Job feared God for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have You not made a hedge around him, around his household, and around all that he has on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out Your hand now, and touch all that he has, and he will curse You to Your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to the Adversary, “Look, all that he has is in your power; only do not stretch out your hand against his person.”
So the Adversary departed from the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: So a day came when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing, and the donkeys were feeding beside them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Sabeans attacked them, and took them away, and they killed the servants with the edge of the sword, and only I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants and consumed them, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three companies and made a raid on the camels and have taken them away. They killed the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, another came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: and suddenly a great wind came from the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell on the young people, and they are dead; and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job stood up, tore his robe, and shaved his head. He fell to the ground and worshipped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said,
“Naked I came from my mother’s womb,
    and naked will I return there.
The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away;
    blessed be the name of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this Job did not sin, and he did not accuse God of wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and the Adversary came also among them to present himself before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord said to the Adversary, “From where do you come?”
And the Adversary answered the Lord, saying, “From roaming on the earth, and from walking up and down on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the Adversary, “Have you considered My servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and an upright man, who fears God and avoids evil? He still holds fast his integrity, although you moved Me against him, to destroy him without cause.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Adversary answered the Lord, saying, “Skin for skin; yes, all that a man has he will give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put forth Your hand now and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse You to Your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to the Adversary, “Very well, he is in your hand, but spare his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, the Adversary went out from the presence of the Lord, and he afflicted Job with severe sores from the sole of his foot to the top of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took a piece of broken pottery with which to scrape himself while he was sitting among the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said to her, “You talk like one of the foolish women talks. Will we indeed accept the good from God but not accept the adversity?”
In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three friends of Job heard about all this evil that had come upon him, and each one came from his own place: Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They had agreed together to come to mourn with him and to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They saw him from a distance and did not recognize him, so they wept aloud. Each one tore his robe, and they tossed dust into the air above their heads.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat down with him on the ground seven days and seven nights. Meanwhile, no one was speaking to him at all because they saw that his pain was severe.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Job opened his mouth, and cursed the day of his birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Job said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let the day perish in which I was born
    and the night in which it was said, ‘A male child is conceived.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Yes, as for that night, let it be barren!
    Let no joyful cry come into it!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them curse it who curse any day,
    those who are prepared to rouse Leviathan.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
because it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb,
    nor hide trouble from my eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why did I not die at birth?
    Why did I not expire when I came out of the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did her knees receive me?
    And why her breasts that I should nurse?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now I would be lying down and would be at peace;
    I would have slept; then there would be rest for me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
with kings and counselors of the earth,
    who built ruins for themselves,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or with princes who had gold,
    who filled their houses with silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or why was I not hidden like a stillborn child,
    like infants who never saw light?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the wicked will have stopped causing trouble,
    and there the exhausted will rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Captives will relax together;
    they do not hear the voice of the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The small and great, they are there,
    and the servant is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why is light given to the miserable,
    and life unto the bitter in soul,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who look for death, but it is not there;
    and they search for it more than for hidden treasures;
speaker: Narrator

text:
who rejoice exceedingly,
    and they are glad when they find the grave?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And why is light given to a man
    whose way is hidden,
    whom God has hedged in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my sighing comes before I eat,
    and my groaning pours forth like the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the thing which I greatly feared has happened to me,
    and that which I dreaded has come to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am not at peace; I have no quiet,
    I cannot rest, and turmoil has come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If one attempts a word with you, will you be impatient?
    But who can keep from speaking?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely you have instructed many,
    and you have strengthened the weak hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your words have raised up him who was falling,
    and you have fortified the feeble knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now it comes upon you, and you are weary;
    it reaches even you, and you are terrified.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not your reverence your confidence?
    And the integrity of your ways your hope?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Remember now, who being innocent ever perished?
    Or where were the upright ever wiped out?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just like I have seen, those who plow iniquity
    and sow trouble, reap the same.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God they perish,
    and by the blast of His anger they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion,
    and the teeth of the young lions are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The old lion perishes for lack of prey,
    and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now a word was brought to me secretly,
    and my ear received a whisper of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Amid disquieting thoughts from night visions,
    when deep sleep falls on mortals,
speaker: Narrator

text:
terror and trembling came to me,
    which made all my bones shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A breath of wind was passing before my face,
    and the hair on my body was standing up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It stood still,
    but I could not recognize its appearance;
a form was in front of my eyes,
    there was stillness, then I heard a voice saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Can a mortal be more righteous than God?
    Can a man be more pure than his Maker?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not trust in His servants,
    and He charges His angels with error;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even more, those who dwell in houses of clay,
    whose foundation is in the dust,
    who are crushed before the moth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are broken in pieces from morning to evening;
    they perish forever without anyone regarding it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are not their tent ropes plucked up,
    so they die, even without wisdom?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Call out now; is anyone answering you?
    And to whom among the holy ones will you turn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For anger slays the foolish man,
    and jealousy kills the gullible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, I saw the foolish taking root,
    and quickly I cursed his dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May his children be far from safety,
    and may they be crushed in the gate without a deliverer;
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose harvest the hungry eats up,
    and takes it even out of the thorns,
    and the thirsty captures his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For affliction does not come out of the dust,
    nor does trouble sprout up out of the ground;
speaker: Narrator

text:
but man is born to trouble,
    as the sparks fly upward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, I would appeal to God,
    and before God I would set forth my case,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who does the great and the inscrutable,
    wonders without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gives rain on the surface of the earth
    and sends water on the outdoor places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sets on high those who are lowly,
    and those who mourn are lifted to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He frustrates the schemes of the crafty,
    so that their hands cannot perform their plans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He catches the wise in their own craftiness,
    and the scheme of the shrewd is swiftly stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the daytime they encounter darkness,
    and at noontime they grope as in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the needy He saves from the sword,
    from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the helpless has hope,
    and injustice shuts her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How happy is the man whom God corrects!
    Therefore do not despise the discipline of the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for He wounds, but He applies the bandage;
    He injures, but His hands also heal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In six crises He will deliver you;
    even in seven, disaster will not touch you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In famine He will redeem you from death,
    and in war from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be hidden from the lash of the tongue,
    and you will not fear violence when it comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will laugh at devastation and famine,
    and you will not fear wild animals.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field,
    and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will know that your tent is peaceful,
    and you will inspect your property and find nothing missing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will know that your offspring will be many
    and your descendants as the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You go to the grave in a full age,
    as stalks of grain are gathered up in season.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look! We have investigated all this, and it is so;
    hear it, and know for yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that my grief were fully weighed,
    and my calamity laid with it on the scales!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea;
    therefore my words are stuck in my throat.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Does the wild donkey bray when he has grass?
    Or the ox bellow over his fodder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is tasteless food eaten without salt?
    Or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul refuses to touch them;
    they are like loathsome food to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that I might have my request,
    and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That it would please God to crush me,
    that He would let loose His hand and cut me off!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“What strength do I have, that I should hope?
    And what is my end, that I should prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is my strength the strength of stones?
    Or is my flesh made of brass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there no help within me?
    And is success banished from me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“A despairing man should be shown kindness from his friend,
    or he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My brothers have acted deceitfully like a riverbed,
    like the streams of the riverbeds that run dry;
speaker: Narrator

text:
which are dark because of the ice,
    and into which the snow disappears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In time they are scorched; they vanish!
    When it is hot, they disappear from their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The caravans of their way turn aside;
    they go nowhere, and they perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The caravans of Tema looked,
    the travelers of Sheba hoped for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were disappointed because they were confident;
    they arrived there and were dismayed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now you are nothing;
    you see terror and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I say, ‘Give to me’?
    Or, ‘Out of your wealth, bribe me’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or, ‘Deliver me from the power of the enemy’?
    Or, ‘From the power of the oppressors, liberate me’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Teach me, and I will hold my tongue,
    and make me understand how I have erred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How forceful are right words!
    But what does your arguing prove?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you mean to correct my words,
    and treat my desperate words as wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you cast lots for the fatherless,
    and you bargain over your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now, please give me your attention,
    for surely I will not lie to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn, I pray, let there be no injustice!
    Yes, turn again, my righteousness still stands!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there injustice on my tongue?
    Cannot my taste discern pernicious things?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is there not a time of hard service for a man upon earth?
    Are not his days also like the days of a hired worker?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a servant, he longs for the shade,
    and like a hired worker, he looks for his wages,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so I have been assigned months of futility,
    and nights of trouble have been appointed to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I lie down, I say,
    ‘When will I arise and the night be ended?’
    And I am full of restlessness until the dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh is covered with worms and caked with dirt;
    my skin is broken, and has become loathsome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My days fly more swiftly than a weaver’s shuttle,
    and are spent without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, remember that my life is a breath!
    My eye will never again see good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye of him who sees me will behold me no more;
    your eyes will be on me, but I will be no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the cloud disappears and vanishes away,
    so he who goes down to Sheol will come up no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will never return to his house,
    and his place will not recognize him anymore.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Am I the sea, or a sea monster,
    that You set a guard over me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me,
    my couch will ease my complaint,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
then You scare me with dreams
    and terrify me with visions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that my soul chooses strangling,
    even death rather than my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I loathe my life; I would not live forever;
    let me alone, for my days are emptiness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is man, that You should exalt him,
    and that You should set Your heart on him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and that You should visit him every morning,
    and test him every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long until You look away from me?
    Will You not let me alone until I swallow my saliva?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I sinned? What am I doing to You,
    O You watcher of men?
Why have You set me as Your target,
    so that I am a burden to myself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And why do You not pardon my transgression
    and take away my iniquity?
For now I will lie down in the dust;
    and You will seek me diligently, but I will not be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you speak these things,
    and the words of your mouth be like a strong wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does God pervert judgment?
    Or does the Almighty pervert justice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your children sinned against Him,
    He cast them away for their transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you yourself would seek God earnestly,
    and seek favor from the Almighty,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though your beginning was small,
    your end will increase greatly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Please, ask the former generation,
    and prepare yourself for what their fathers searched out;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for we were born but yesterday and know nothing,
    because our days on earth are a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they not teach you, and tell you,
    and bring forth words out of their heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can the papyrus grow up without a marsh?
    Can the reed grow without water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
While it is yet green and not cut down,
    it withers before any other plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So are the paths of all who forget God;
    and the hypocrite’s hope will perish,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose confidence will be cut off,
    and whose trust will be a spider’s web.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will lean upon his house, but it will not stand;
    he will hold it fast, but it will not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is green before the sun,
    and his branch shoots forth in his garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots are wrapped around the rock heap,
    and he sees the place of stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he is uprooted from his place,
    then it will deny him, saying, ‘I have not seen you.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, this is the joy of his way,
    and out of the ground others will grow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely, God will not cast away a perfect man,
    nor will He strengthen the evildoers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
until He fills your mouth with laughing,
    and your lips with rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who hate you will be clothed with shame,
    and the dwelling place of the wicked will come to nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Truly, I know it is so,
    but how can a man be righteous with God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one would dispute with Him,
    he cannot answer Him once in a thousand times.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is wise in heart and mighty in strength.
    Who has hardened himself against Him and prospered?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who removes mountains, and they know not,
    who overturns them in His anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who shakes the earth out of its place,
    and its pillars tremble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who commands the sun, and it does not rise;
    he seals off the stars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who alone spreads out the heavens,
    and treads on the waves of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who makes the Bear, Orion, and Pleiades,
    and the constellations of the south.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who does great things, beyond discovery,
    yes, and wonders beyond number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, He would cross before me, and I would not see Him;
    He would pass on by, but I would not perceive Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, He takes away; who can hinder Him?
    Who will say to Him, ‘What are You doing?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
God will not withdraw His anger.
    The proud helpers bow down beneath Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How, then, can I myself answer Him,
    and choose my words to reason with Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even if I were righteous I could not answer;
    I would plead to my Judge for favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I called, and He answered me,
    I would not believe that He had listened to my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He crushes me with a storm
    and multiplies my wounds without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not allow me to get my breath,
    but fills me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If it is a matter of strength, indeed, He is strong;
    and if of justice, who will set me a time to plead?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me;
    though I were perfect, it would prove me perverse.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
It is all one thing; therefore I said,
    ‘He destroys both the perfect and the wicked.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the whip kills suddenly,
    He will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked.
    He covers the faces of its judges.
    If it is not He, then who is it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now my days are swifter than a runner;
    they flee away; they see no good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pass by like reed skiffs,
    like an eagle rushing upon its prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint;
    I will leave off my sad face and brighten up,’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am afraid of all my sorrows;
    I know that You will not hold me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I am guilty,
    why then do I labor in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wash myself with snow water
    and cleanse my hands with soap,
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet You will plunge me into the pit,
    and my own clothes will abhor me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For He is not a man as I am, that I should answer Him,
    and we should come together in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nor is there a mediator between us,
    who may lay his hand upon us both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let Him take His rod away from me,
    and let not dread of Him terrify me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I would speak and not fear Him,
    but it is not so with me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will say to God, Do not condemn me;
    show me why You contend with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it good for You that You should oppress,
    that You should despise the work of Your hands
    and smile on the counsel of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do You have eyes of flesh?
    Or do You see as man sees?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are Your days as the days of man?
    Are Your years as the days of a mortal,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that You inquire after my iniquity
    and search after my sin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know that I am not wicked,
    and there is none who can deliver out of Your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Your hands have shaped me and made me completely,
    yet You destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember, I pray,
    that You have made me as the clay.
    And would You return me to dust?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have You not poured me out as milk
    and curdled me like cheese?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have clothed me with skin and flesh,
    and have knit me together with bones and sinews.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have granted me life and loyal love,
    and Your care has preserved my spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“These things You have hid in Your heart.
    I know that this is with You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have sinned, then You would watch me,
    and You would not acquit me from my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For if my head is lifted up, You would hunt me like a lion,
    and again You show Yourself marvelous to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You renew Your witnesses against me
    and increase Your indignation upon me.
    Your troops come against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why then did You bring me forth out of the womb?
    Oh, that I had died, and no eye had seen me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I should have been as though I had not been;
    I should have been carried from the womb to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are not my days few? Stop then,
    and leave me alone that I may cheer up a little,
speaker: Narrator

text:
before I go and do not return,
    even to the land of darkness and the shadow of death,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should not the multitude of words be answered?
    And should a man full of talk be justified?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should your empty talk make men hold their peace?
    And when you mock, will no one shame you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have said, ‘My teaching is pure,
    And I am clean in your eyes.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But oh, that God would speak
    and open His lips against you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and that He would show you the secrets of wisdom!
    For they would double your prudence.
    And know that God overlooks some of your iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you search out the deep things of God?
    Can you find out the totality of the Almighty?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is as high as heaven; what can you do?
    Deeper than Sheol; what can you know?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its measure is longer than the earth
    and broader than the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If He passes through, and shuts up, and gathers together for judgment,
    then who can hinder Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He knows worthless men;
    He sees wickedness also; will He not then consider it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For an empty-headed man will become wise,
    when a wild donkey’s colt is born a man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you prepare your heart
    and stretch out your hands toward Him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if iniquity is in your hand, put it far away,
    and do not let wickedness dwell in your tents;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for then you will lift up your face without blemish;
    yes, you will be steadfast and will not fear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because you will forget misery,
    and remember it as waters that pass away,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and your life will be brighter than noonday,
    even your darkness will be as the morning.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Also you will lie down, and none will make you afraid;
    yes, many will court your favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the eyes of the wicked will fail,
    and they will not escape,
    and their hope will be as the giving up of breath.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“No doubt but you are the people,
    and wisdom will die with you!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
He whose foot is unsteady
    is despised in the thoughts of him who is at ease.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tents of robbers are at peace,
    and those who provoke God are secure,
    into whose hand they bring their own god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But now ask the beasts, and let them teach you;
    and the birds of the air, and let them tell you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
or speak to the earth, let it teach you;
    and let the fish of the sea declare to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who among all these does not know
    that the hand of the Lord has done this,
speaker: Narrator

text:
in whose hand is the soul of every living thing
    and the breath of all mankind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not the ear test words
    and the mouth taste its food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is with the elderly,
    and understanding comes with long life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“With Him are wisdom and strength;
    He has counsel and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely, He tears down, and it cannot be built again;
    He imprisons a man, and there can be no release.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely, He withholds the waters, and they dry up;
    also He sends them out, and they overthrow the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With Him are strength and wisdom.
    The deceived and the deceiver are His.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads counselors away stripped
    and makes fools of judges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has loosened the bonds imposed by kings
    and bound their waist with a belt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leads away priests stripped
    and overthrows the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He removes speech from the trusted ones
    and takes away the understanding of the aged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He pours contempt upon princes
    and loosens the belt of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He uncovers deep things out of darkness
    and brings the shadow of death to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He increases the nations and destroys them;
    He enlarges the nations and guides them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He takes away the understanding of the chiefs of the people of the earth,
    and causes them to wander in a wilderness where there is no way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They grope in the dark without light,
    and He makes them to stagger like a drunk man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Notice, my eye has seen all this;
    my ear has heard and understood it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What you know, I also know the same;
    I am not inferior to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would speak to the Almighty,
    and I desire to reason with God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you are plasterers of falsehood;
    you are all physicians of no value.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that you would altogether hold your peace,
    and it would be your wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear now my reasoning,
    and listen to the pleadings of my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you speak wickedly for God?
    And talk deceitfully for Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you take His side?
    Will you plead for God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it good that He would search you out?
    Or as one man mocks another, do you so mock Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will surely rebuke you,
    if you secretly show partiality.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will not His excellence make you afraid,
    and the dread of Him fall upon you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your reminders are parables made of ashes;
    your answers are answers made of clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hold your peace; leave me alone, that I may speak,
    and let come on me what may!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do I take my flesh in my teeth
    and put my life in my hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though He slay me, yet will I trust in Him,
    but I will defend my own ways before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He also will be my salvation,
    for a hypocrite could not come before Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen carefully to my speech,
    and to my declaration with your ears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See now, I have prepared my case;
    I know that I will be justified.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is he who will plead with me?
    For now, if I hold my tongue, I will give up my breath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Only grant me two things,
    then I will not hide myself from You:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Withdraw Your hand far from me,
    and let not the dread of You make me afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then call, and I will answer;
    or let me speak, and You answer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How many are my iniquities and sins?
    Make known to me my transgression and my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do You hide Your face
    and regard me as Your enemy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will You frighten a leaf driven to and fro?
    And will You pursue dry stubble?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You write bitter things against me
    and make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Man, as a rotten thing, decays,
    as a garment that is moth eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Man who is born of a woman
    is of few days and full of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He comes forth like a flower and withers;
    he flees like a shadow and does not continue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do You open Your eyes on such a one,
    and bring me into judgment with You?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean?
    There is no one.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
turn from him, that he may rest,
    until he, as a hired man, finishes his day.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though its root may grow old in the earth,
    and its stump may die in the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet at the scent of water it will bud
    and bring forth boughs like a plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But man dies and wastes away;
    yes, man gives up his breath, and where is he?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the waters disappear from the sea,
    and the flood shrivels and dries up,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Oh, that You would hide me in the grave,
    that You would conceal me until Your wrath is past,
that You would appoint me a set time
    and remember me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a man dies, will he live again?
    All the days of my service I will wait,
    until my relief comes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will call, and I will answer You;
    You will long for the work of Your hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now You number my steps;
    do You not observe my sin?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My transgression is sealed up in a bag,
    and You plaster over my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely the mountain falling comes to nothing,
    and the rock is removed out of its place.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You prevail forever against him, and he passes on;
    changing his countenance, You send him away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sons come to honor, and he does not know it;
    and they are brought low, but he does not perceive it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But his flesh on him will have pain,
    and his soul within him will mourn.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should a wise man reply with empty knowledge
    and fill his lungs with the east wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he reason with unprofitable talk
    or with speeches with which he can do no good?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, you cast off reverence
    and hinder prayer before God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For your mouth utters your iniquity,
    and you choose the tongue of the crafty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your own mouth condemns you, and not I;
    yes, your own lips testify against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Are you the first man who was born?
    Or were you made before the hills?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you heard the counsel of God?
    And do you restrict wisdom to yourself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you know that we do not know?
    What do you understand that is not in us?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Both the gray-haired and very aged are among us—
    much older than your father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are the consolations of God too small for you?
    Or the word spoken gently to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why does your heart carry you away?
    And what do your eyes wink at,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you turn your spirit against God,
    and let such words go out of your mouth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What is man that he should be pure?
    And he who is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, He puts no trust in His holy ones,
    and the heavens are not pure in His sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much more abhorred and corrupt is man,
    who drinks iniquity like water!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will tell you; hear me,
    and what I have seen I will declare,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what wise men have told,
    not hiding anything received from their fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to whom alone the land was given,
    and no foreigner passed among them:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked man travails with pain all his days,
    and numbered are the years stored up for the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A dreadful sound is in his ears;
    in prosperity the destroyer will come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not believe that he will return from darkness,
    and a sword awaits him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He wanders about for bread, saying, ‘Where is it?’
    He knows that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trouble and anguish will make him afraid;
    they will prevail against him as a king ready to the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he stretches out his hand against God,
    and strengthens himself against the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rushes upon Him, even on His neck,
    with his thick embossed shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He has covered his face with his fatness
    and gathered fat upon his waist.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dwells in desolate cities
    and in houses which no man inhabits,
    which are ready to become heaps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not be rich, nor will his wealth continue,
    nor will his possessions spread over the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Let him who is deceived not trust in futility,
    for futility will be his reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be accomplished before his time,
    and his branch will not be green.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will shake off his unripe grape like the vine,
    and will cast off his blossom like the olive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the company of hypocrites will be desolate,
    and fire will consume the tents of bribery.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They conceive mischief, and give birth to futility;
    their womb prepares deceit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have heard many such things;
    miserable comforters are you all!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will windy words have an end?
    Or what provokes you that you answer?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also could speak as you do,
    if your soul were in my place.
I could heap up words against you
    and shake my head at you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
but I would strengthen you with my mouth,
    and the moving of my lips would relieve your grief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Though I speak, my grief is not relieved;
    and though I stop, how am I eased?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now He has made me weary;
    You have made desolate all my company.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have filled me with wrinkles, which is a witness against me;
    and my leanness has risen up and bears witness to my face.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
God has delivered me to the ungodly
    and turned me over into the hands of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was at ease, but He has shattered me.
    He also has taken me by my neck, and shaken me to pieces,
and set me up for His target.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He pierces me with thrust after thrust;
    He rushes upon me like a warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have sewn sackcloth over my skin
    and thrust my horn into the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My face is inflamed with weeping,
    and on my eyelids is the shadow of death,
speaker: Narrator

text:
though not for any violence in my hands,
    and my prayer is pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“O earth, do not cover my blood,
    and let my cry have no resting place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also now, look, my witness is in heaven,
    and my record is on high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My friends scorn me;
    my eyes pour out tears unto God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that one might plead for a man with God,
    as a man pleads for his neighbor!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For when a few years have passed,
    I will go the way from which I will not return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“My spirit is broken,
    my days are extinguished,
    the grave is ready for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are not mockers with me?
    And does not my eye dwell on their provocation?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now put down a pledge for me with Yourself.
    Who is he who will shake hands with me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You have hidden their heart from understanding.
    Therefore will You not exalt them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who speaks flattery to his friends,
    even the eyes of his children will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And He has made me a byword of the people,
    someone in whose face they spit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My eye also is dim because of sorrow,
    and all my members are like a shadow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upright men will be astonished at this,
    and the innocent will stir up himself against the hypocrite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous also will hold to his way,
    and he who has clean hands will be stronger and stronger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But as for you all, return and come now,
    for I cannot find one wise man among you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are past, my purposes are broken off,
    even the thoughts of my heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They change the night into day;
    the light is short because of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wait, the grave is my house;
    I have made my bed in the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have said to the pit, ‘You are my father’;
    to the worm, ‘You are my mother and my sister.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where now is my hope?
    As for my hope, who will see it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will they go down to the gates of Sheol?
    Will we descend together in the dust?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will it be until you put an end to words?
    Gain understanding, and afterwards we will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why are we counted as beasts
    and regarded as stupid in your sight?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You who tear yourself in anger,
    will the earth be forsaken for you?
    And will the rock be removed from its place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Yes, the light of the wicked will be put out,
    and the spark of his fire will not shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light will be dark in his tent,
    and his candle beside him will be put out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The steps of his strength will be shortened,
    and his own counsel will cast him down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he is cast into a net by his own feet,
    and he walks upon a snare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The trap will take him by the heel,
    and the snare will prevail against him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The snare is laid for him in the ground,
    and a trap for him in the path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors will make him afraid on every side
    and will drive him to his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His strength will be hungry,
    and destruction will be ready at his side.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will devour the parts of his skin;
    the firstborn of death will devour his limbs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His confidence will be rooted out of his tent,
    and it will bring him to the king of terrors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They dwell in his tent who have no part with him;
    brimstone will be scattered upon his habitation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots will be dried up beneath,
    and above his branch will dry up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The memory of him will perish from the earth,
    and he will have no name in the street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will be driven from light into darkness,
    and chased out of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has neither descendant nor posterity among his people,
    nor anyone remaining in his dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They who come after him will be astonished at his day,
    as they who went before were seized with fright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely such are the dwellings of the wicked,
    and this is the place of him who does not know God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long will you torment my soul
    and break me in pieces with words?
speaker: Narrator

text:
These ten times you have reproached me;
    you are not ashamed that you have wronged me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if indeed I have erred,
    my error remains with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If indeed you exalt yourselves against me
    and plead against me with my disgrace,
speaker: Narrator

text:
know now that God has bent me
    and has surrounded me with His net.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, I cry out concerning wrong, but I am not heard;
    I cry aloud, but there is no justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has fenced up my way that I cannot pass,
    and He has set darkness in my paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has stripped me of my glory
    and taken the crown from my head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has destroyed me on every side, and I am gone;
    my hope He has uprooted like a tree.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has also kindled His wrath against me,
    and He counts me as one of His enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“He has removed my brothers far from me,
    and my acquaintances are completely estranged from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My relatives have failed,
    and my close friends have forgotten me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I called my servant, but he gave me no answer;
    I begged him with my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My breath is offensive to my wife;
    I am loathsome to the children of my own body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, young children despise me;
    I arose, and they spoke against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All my close friends abhorred me,
    and they whom I love are turned against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bones cling to my skin and to my flesh,
    and I have escaped by the skin of my teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O you my friends,
    for the hand of God has struck me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you persecute me as God does,
    and are not satisfied with my flesh?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that my words were written!
    Oh, that they were inscribed in a book!
speaker: Narrator

text:
That they were engraved with an iron pen
    and lead in the rock forever!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that my Redeemer lives,
    and He will stand at last on the earth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and after my skin is destroyed,
    yet in my flesh I will see God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whom I will see for myself,
    and my eyes will behold, and not another.
    How my heart yearns within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If you should say, ‘How shall we persecute him?’
    since the root of the matter is found in me,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore my thoughts cause me to answer,
    and for this I make haste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard the rebuke that disgraces me,
    and the spirit of my understanding causes me to answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you not know this of old,
    since man was placed upon earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that the triumphing of the wicked is short,
    and the joy of the hypocrite is but for a moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:
