text:
They came upon me as a wide breach, with a crash they came;
    in the desolation they rolled themselves upon me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Now my soul is poured out within me;
    the days of affliction have taken hold of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bones are pierced in me at night,
    and my sinews have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the great force of my disease my garment is changed;
    it binds me about as the collar of my coat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has cast me into the mire,
    and I have become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I cry unto You, but You do not hear me;
    I stand up, and You do not regard me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have become cruel to me;
    with Your strong hand You oppose me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You lift me up to the wind and cause me to ride on it;
    You dissolve my success.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that You will bring me to death,
    and to the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely He will not stretch out His hand to the grave,
    though they cry when He destroys it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I not weep for him who was in trouble?
    Was not my soul grieved for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I looked for good, then evil disaster came upon me;
    and when I waited for light, darkness came.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My insides boiled and did not rest;
    the days of affliction have met me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went mourning without the sun;
    I stood up, and I cried in the congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a brother of jackals
    and a companion of owls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin is black upon me,
    and my bones are burned with fever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My harp is turned to mourning,
    and my flute to the voice of those who weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I made a covenant with my eyes;
    why then should I look upon a young woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what portion of God is there from above?
    And what inheritance of the Almighty from on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not destruction belong to the wicked,
    and calamity to the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does He not see my ways,
    and count all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have walked in vanity,
    or if my foot has hurried after deceit,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let me be weighed in an even balance
    that God may know my integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If my step has turned out of the path,
    and my heart has gone after my eyes,
    and if any spot has clung to my hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let me sow, but let another eat;
    yes, let my offspring be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my heart has been deceived by a woman,
    or if I have laid wait at my neighbor’s door,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife grind for another,
    and let others bow down over her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is a heinous crime;
    yes, it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is a fire that consumes to destruction
    and would root out all my increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have despised the cause of my male or female servant
    when they complained against me,
speaker: Narrator

text:
what then will I do when God rises up?
    And when He visits, what will I answer Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did not He who made me in the womb make him?
    And did not the same One fashion us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have kept the poor from their desire,
    or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or have eaten my morsel by myself,
    so that the fatherless could not eat of it
speaker: Narrator

text:
(but from my youth he was brought up with me, as with a father,
    and I have guided the widow from my mother’s womb);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing,
    or any poor without covering;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if his body has not blessed me,
    and if he was not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless,
    when I saw I had help in the gate;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my arm fall from my shoulder blade,
    and my arm be broken from the bone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For destruction from God is a terror to me,
    and because of His highness I cannot endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I have made gold my hope,
    or have said to the fine gold, ‘You are my confidence’;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I rejoiced because my wealth was great,
    and because my hand had gained much;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I saw the sun when it shined,
    or the moon moving in brightness;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and my heart has been secretly enticed,
    or my mouth has kissed my hand;
speaker: Narrator

text:
this also would be an iniquity to be punished by the judge,
    for I would have denied the God who is above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If I rejoiced at the destruction of him who hated me,
    or lifted up myself when disaster found him
speaker: Narrator

text:
(nor have I allowed my mouth to sin
    by wishing for a curse on his soul);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if the men of my tent have not said,
    ‘Who is there who has not been satisfied with his meat?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
(the stranger has not lodged in the street,
    but I opened my doors to the traveler);
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I covered my transgressions as any man,
    by hiding my iniquity in my heart,
speaker: Narrator

text:
did I fear a great multitude,
    or did the contempt of families terrify me,
    so that I kept silence, and did not go out of the door?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Oh, that one would hear me!
    Behold, my desire is that the Almighty would answer me,
    and that the One who contends against me had written a book!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would carry it on my shoulder
    and bind it on me like a crown.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would declare to Him the number of my steps;
    like a prince I would approach Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If my land cries out against me,
    and its furrows also weep together;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have eaten its fruit without money,
    or have caused its owners to lose their life;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: So these three men ceased answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the wrath of Elihu the son of Barakel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, was aroused; his wrath was aroused against Job because he justified himself rather than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wrath was aroused also against his three friends because they had found no answer and yet had condemned Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elihu had waited until Job had spoken because they were older than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, then his wrath was aroused.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihu the son of Barakel the Buzite answered:
“I am young,
    and you are very old;
therefore I was afraid
    and dared not show you my opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Age should speak,
    and multitude of years should teach wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a spirit in man,
    and the breath of the Almighty gives him understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great men are not always wise,
    nor do the aged always understand judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore I say,
    ‘Listen to me; I will also declare my opinion.’
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Lest you say, ‘We have found wisdom’;
    God will subdue him, not man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now he has not directed his words against me,
    so I will not answer him with your speeches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They are amazed; they answer no more;
    they cease speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I have waited,
    (for they did not speak, but stood still and answered no more).
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘I also will answer my part;
    I too will show my opinion.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am full of words;
    the spirit within me compels me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, my belly is like wine that has no vent;
    it is ready to burst like new wineskins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will speak, that I may be refreshed;
    I will open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me not, I pray, show partiality to anyone,
    nor let me give flattering titles to man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I do not know how to give flattering titles;
    in so doing my Maker would soon take me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore, Job, I pray, hear my speeches,
    and listen to all my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, now I have opened my mouth;
    my tongue has spoken in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words will be from the uprightness of my heart,
    and my lips will utter knowledge clearly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of God has made me,
    and the breath of the Almighty has given me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you can answer me,
    set your words in order before me; stand up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I am before God like you;
    I also am formed out of the clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, no dread of me will make you afraid,
    nor will my hand be heavy upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Surely you have spoken in my hearing,
    and I have heard the sound of your words, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I am clean, without transgression;
    I am innocent, nor is there iniquity in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, He finds occasions against me,
    He counts me for His enemy;
speaker: Narrator

text:
He puts my feet in the stocks,
    He watches all my paths.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, in this you are not just.
    I will answer you, that God is greater than man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you strive against Him?
    For He does not give an accounting for any of His words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God speaks once, yes twice,
    yet man does not perceive it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a dream, in a vision of the night,
    when deep sleep falls upon men,
    in slumber on their beds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then He opens the ears of men,
    and seals their instruction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that He might turn aside man from his purpose,
    and conceal pride from man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keeps back his soul from the pit,
    and his life from perishing by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is also chastened with pain on his bed,
    and with strong pain in many of his bones,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that his life abhors bread,
    and his soul dainty food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh is consumed away that it cannot be seen,
    and his bones that were not seen stick out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, his soul draws near to the grave,
    and his life to the executioners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If there is a messenger for him,
    an interpreter, one among a thousand,
    to show to man what is right for him,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
His flesh will be fresher than a child’s;
    he will return to the days of his youth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he will pray to God, and He will be favorable unto him,
    and he will see His face with joy,
    for He will render unto man His righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he looks at men and says,
    ‘I have sinned and perverted what was right,
    and it did not profit me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will deliver his soul from going down to the pit,
    and his life will see the light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God works all these things,
    twice, three times with man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring back his soul from the pit,
    to be enlightened with the light of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Pay attention, Job, listen to me;
    hold your peace, and I will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have anything to say, answer me;
    speak, for I desire to justify you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, listen to me; hold your peace,
    and I will teach you wisdom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore Elihu answered and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Hear my words, O you wise men;
    and give ear unto me, you that have knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the ear tests words,
    as the mouth tastes food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us choose justice for ourselves;
    let us know among ourselves what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For Job has said, ‘I am righteous,
    but God has taken away my judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should I lie concerning my right?
    My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
What man is like Job,
    who drinks scorn like water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who goes in company with the workers of iniquity
    and walks with wicked men?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he has said, ‘It profits a man nothing
    that he should delight himself in God.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore listen to me, you men of understanding:
    Far be it from God that He should do wickedness,
    and from the Almighty that He should commit iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will repay a man for his work,
    and cause every man to find what is according to his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, surely God will not do wickedly,
    nor will the Almighty pervert judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has given Him charge over the earth?
    Or who has set in order the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If He sets His heart on man,
    if He gathers unto Himself His Spirit and His breath,
speaker: Narrator

text:
all flesh will perish together,
    and man will turn again to dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“If now you have understanding, hear this;
    listen to the voice of my words:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should he who hates justice govern?
    And will you condemn Him who is most just?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it fitting to say to a king, ‘You are wicked’?
    And to princes, ‘You are ungodly’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet He is not partial to princes,
    nor does He regard the rich more than the poor.
    For they all are the work of His hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a moment they will die,
    and the people will be troubled at midnight and pass away,
    and the mighty will be taken away without a hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For His eyes are upon the ways of man,
    and He sees all his goings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no darkness nor shadow of death
    where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He will not lay upon man more than right,
    that he should enter into judgment with God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will break in pieces mighty men without number,
    and set others in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore He knows their works,
    and He overturns them in the night
    so that they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He strikes them as wicked men
    in the open sight of others,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they turned back from Him
    and would not consider any of His ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto Him;
    and He hears the cry of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When He gives quietness, who then can make trouble?
    And when He hides His face, who then can behold Him,
whether it is done against a nation or against a man only?
speaker: Narrator

text:
That the hypocrite should not reign,
    lest the people be ensnared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Should anyone say to God,
    ‘I have borne chastisement, I will offend no more;
speaker: Narrator

text:
teach me what I do not see;
    if I have done iniquity, I will do no more’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should it be according to your mind?
    He will repay it, whether you refuse or whether you choose,
    and not I; therefore speak what you know.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Let men of understanding say to me,
    wise men who listen to me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Job has spoken without knowledge,
    and his words were without wisdom.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
My desire is that Job may be tried unto the end,
    because he answers like wicked men.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Elihu spoke again and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you think this is right,
    that you say, ‘My righteousness is before God’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you said, ‘What advantage will it be to me?
    What profit will I have if I am cleansed from my sin?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will answer you,
    and your companions with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look unto the heavens and see,
    and behold the clouds that are higher than you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you sin, what do you accomplish against Him?
    Or if your transgressions are multiplied, what does it do to Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are righteous, what does it give Him?
    Or what does He receive from your hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your wickedness may hurt a man like you,
    and your righteousness may profit a son of man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because of the many oppressions they cry out;
    they cry out because of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But none says, ‘Where is God my Maker,
    who gives songs in the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth,
    and makes us wiser than the birds of heaven?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they cry out, but He does not answer
    because of the pride of evil men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God will not hear vanity,
    nor will the Almighty regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although you say you do not see Him,
    yet judgment is before Him,
    and you must trust in Him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now, because He has not punished in His anger,
    nor taken much notice of folly,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore Job opens his mouth in vain;
    he multiplies words without knowledge.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu continued and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bear with me a little, and I will show you
    that I have yet to speak on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring my knowledge from afar
    and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For truly my words will not be false;
    He who is perfect in knowledge is with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is mighty and despises no one;
    He is mighty in strength and wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He does not preserve the life of the wicked,
    but gives justice to the poor.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
If they are bound in chains
    and held in cords of affliction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then He shows them their work,
    and their transgressions that they have exceeded;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and He opens their ear to discipline,
    and commands that they turn from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they obey and serve Him,
    they will spend their days in prosperity
    and their years in pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they do not obey,
    they will perish by the sword,
    and they will die without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But the hypocrites in heart heap up wrath;
    they do not cry out when He binds them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in youth,
    and their life ends among the unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivers the poor in their affliction,
    and opens their ears in oppression.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But you are filled with the judgment due the wicked;
    judgment and justice take hold of you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because there is wrath, beware lest He take you away with a blow;
    even a great ransom cannot deliver you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will He esteem your riches?
    No, not gold, nor all the force of your strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not desire the night,
    when people are cut off in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take heed! Do not turn to iniquity,
    for you have chosen this rather than affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, God is exalted in His power;
    who teaches like Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has prescribed His way for Him?
    Or who can say, ‘You have worked iniquity’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember to magnify His work,
    which men behold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every man may see it;
    man may behold it from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, God is great, and we do not know Him,
    nor can the number of His years be searched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For He draws up the drops of water;
    they distill rain according to its mist,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which the clouds drop down,
    and drip upon man abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, can anyone understand the spreading of clouds,
    or the noise of His tent?
speaker: Narrator

text:
See, He spreads His light upon it
    and covers the bottom of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by these He judges the people;
    He gives food in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With clouds He covers the light,
    and commands it to strike the mark.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its thunder declares it,
    the cattle also, concerning the rising storm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“At this also my heart trembles
    and moves out of its place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear attentively the thunder of His voice,
    and the sound that goes out of His mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lets it loose under the whole heaven,
    and His lightning unto the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After it a voice roars; He thunders with His majestic voice,
    and He does not restrain them when His voice is heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God thunders marvelously with His voice;
    He does great things that we cannot comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For He says to the snow, ‘Come on the earth,’
    likewise to the gentle rain and to the heavy rain of His strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He seals up the hand of every man,
    that all men may know His work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the beasts go into dens
    and remain in their places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the south comes the whirlwind,
    and cold out of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God frost is given,
    and the broad waters are frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also He loads the thick clouds with moisture;
    He scatters His bright clouds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they are turned about by His guidance,
    that they may do whatever He commands them
    upon the face of the inhabited earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He causes it to come, whether for correction,
    or for His land or for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen to this, Job; stand still
    and consider the wondrous works of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know when God dispatches them
    and causes the light of His cloud to shine?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know how the clouds are balanced,
    the wondrous works of Him who is perfect in knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How your garments are warm,
    when He quiets the earth by the south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you, with Him, spread out the sky,
    which is strong and is like a molded mirror?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Teach us what we will say to Him,
    for we cannot prepare our speech because of the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it be told Him that I speak?
    If a man speaks, surely he will be swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now men do not see the bright light
    which is in the clouds,
    but the wind passes and cleanses them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fair weather comes out of the north;
    with God is terrible majesty.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Men therefore fear Him;
    He shows no partiality to those who are wise in heart.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who is this who darkens counsel
    by words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Where were you when I laid the foundations of the earth?
    Declare, if you have understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has determined its measurements, if you know?
    Or who has stretched the line upon it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To what are its foundations fastened?
    Or who laid its cornerstone
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the morning stars sang together,
    and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Or who shut up the sea with doors
    when it broke forth and went out of the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I made the cloud its garment,
    and thick darkness its swaddling band,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and broke up for it My decreed place,
    and set bars and doors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, ‘This far you will come but no farther,
    and here your proud waves will be stopped’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you commanded the morning in your days,
    and caused the dawn to know its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that it might take hold of the ends of the earth,
    that the wicked might be shaken out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is turned like clay by the seal,
    and it stands out as a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the wicked their light is withheld,
    and the high arm will be broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered into the springs of the sea?
    Or have you walked in search of the depths?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been opened to you?
    Or have you seen the doors of the shadow of death?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you perceived the breadth of the earth?
    Declare, if you know it all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where is the path where light dwells?
    And as for darkness, where is its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you should take it to its boundary,
    and that you should know the paths to its house?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know it because you were born then,
    or because the number of your days is many?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered the treasuries of the snow?
    Or have you seen the treasuries of the hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I have reserved against the time of trouble,
    against the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
By what way is the light diffused,
    or the east wind scattered upon the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has divided a channel for the overflowing waters,
    or a path for the thunderbolt,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to cause it to rain on the earth where no man is,
    on the wilderness in which there are no people,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy the desolate waste,
    and to cause the bud of the tender herb to spring forth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the rain have a father?
    Or who has produced the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From whose womb came the ice?
    And the frost of heaven, who gives it birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters harden like stone,
    and the surface of the deep is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you tie the cords to the Pleiades
    or loosen the belt of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bring out the constellation in its season?
    Or can you guide the Bear with its cubs?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know the ordinances of heaven?
    Can you set their dominion over the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you lift up your voice to the clouds,
    that abundance of waters may cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send lightning that they may go forth
    and say to you, ‘Here we are’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has put wisdom in the inward parts,
    or who has given understanding to the heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can number the clouds by wisdom?
    Or who can empty out the bottles of heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the dust turns into hard clumps
    and the clods stick together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will you hunt the prey for the lion?
    Or fill the appetite of the young lions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they crouch in their dens
    and lie in the thicket to wait in ambush?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who provides for the raven his food
    when his young ones cry unto God,
    and they wander about for lack of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know the time when the wild mountain goats produce offspring?
    Or can you observe when the deer gives birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you number the months that they fulfill,
    or do you know the time when they bring forth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They bow themselves, they bring forth their young ones,
    they get rid of their labor pains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young ones are healthy, they grow strong with grain;
    they go forth and do not return to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has sent out the wild donkey free?
    Or who has loosed the bands of the wild donkey,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose home I have made the wilderness,
    and the barren land his dwelling?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He scorns the multitude in the city
    and does not regard the shouts of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The range of the mountains is his pasture,
    and he searches after every green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will the wild ox be willing to serve you
    or spend the night by your manger?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you bind the wild ox in the furrow with ropes?
    Or will he plow the valleys behind you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him because his strength is great?
    Or will you leave your labor to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you trust him to bring home your grain
    and gather it into your barn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Did you give the beautiful wings to the peacocks?
    Or wings and feathers to the ostrich,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who leaves her eggs in the earth,
    and warms them in dust,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and forgets that a foot may crush them,
    or that the wild beast may break them?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
because God has deprived her of wisdom,
    nor has He imparted understanding to her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When she lifts up herself on high,
    she scorns the horse and his rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you given the horse strength?
    Have you clothed his neck with thunder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you make him afraid like a grasshopper?
    The glory of his nostrils is awesome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength;
    he goes on to meet the armed men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mocks at fear and is not frightened,
    nor does he turn back from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The quiver rattles against him,
    the glittering spear and the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He devours the distance with fierceness and rage,
    and he does not stand still at the sound of the trumpet.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Does the hawk fly by your wisdom,
    and stretch her wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does the eagle mount up at your command
    and make her nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
She dwells and remains on the rock,
    upon the crag of the rock, and the strong place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there she seeks the prey,
    and her eyes see it from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her young ones also suck up blood,
    and where the slain are, there she is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the Lord answered Job and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Will he who argues with the Almighty instruct Him?
    He who rebukes God, let him answer it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Behold, I am vile; what shall I answer You?
    I will lay my hand over my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once have I spoken, but I will not answer;
    yes, twice, but I will proceed no further.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Will you indeed annul My judgment?
    Will you condemn Me, that you may be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you an arm like God?
    Or can you thunder with a voice like Him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adorn yourself now with majesty and excellence,
    and array yourself with glory and beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let loose the rage of your wrath,
    and look on every one who is proud and abase him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
look on every one who is proud and bring him low,
    and tread down the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them in the dust together,
    and imprison them in the hidden place of the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will also confess to you
    that your own right hand can save you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
See now his strength is in his hips,
    and his power is in the muscles of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He moves his tail like a cedar;
    the sinews of his thighs are wrapped together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are like strong pieces of brass;
    his bones are like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the first of the works of God;
    He who made him can bring near His sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the mountains bring forth food for him,
    where all the beasts of the field play.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lies under the shady trees,
    in the thicket of the reed and marsh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The shady trees cover him with their shadow;
    the willows of the brook surround him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, the river rages, but he is not alarmed;
    he trusts that he can draw up the Jordan into his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can anyone catch it by its eyes,
    or pierce its nose with a snare?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw out Leviathan with a hook
    or snare his tongue with a line which you let down?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a cord into his nose,
    or pierce his jaw with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make many supplications to you?
    Will he speak soft words to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make a covenant with you?
    Will you take him for a servant forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you play with him as with a bird?
    Or will you put him on a leash for your maidens?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will your companions make a banquet of him?
    Will they divide him among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill his skin with harpoons
    or his head with fishing spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay your hand on him;
    remember the battle—you will do it no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Notice, any hope of overcoming him is in vain;
    shall not one be overwhelmed at the sight of him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one is so fierce that he dares to stir him up.
    Who then is able to stand before Me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has preceded Me that I should repay him?
    Everything under heaven is Mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not conceal his limbs,
    nor his power, nor his graceful proportions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can remove his outer garment?
    Or who can approach him with a double bridle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the jaws of his face?
    His teeth are terrible all around.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His scales are his pride,
    shut up tightly as with a seal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is so near to another
    that no air can come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined to each other;
    they stick together that they cannot be separated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His sneezing flashes forth light,
    and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his mouth go burning lights,
    and sparks of fire leap out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his nostrils goes smoke
    as out of a seething pot or cauldron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breath kindles coals,
    and a flame goes out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his neck remains strength,
    and sorrow is turned into joy before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The folds of his flesh are joined together;
    they are firm on him; they cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His heart is as firm as a stone,
    yes, as hard as a piece of the lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he raises up himself even the gods are afraid;
    because of his crashings they are beside themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sword that reaches him cannot avail,
    nor does the spear, the arrow, or the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He counts iron as straw,
    and brass as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrow cannot make him flee;
    slingstones are turned into stubble by him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arrows are counted as straw;
    he laughs at the shaking of a spear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sharp stones are his underside;
    he leaves a mark in the mire like a sharp threshing sledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes the deep to boil like a pot;
    he makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He leaves a shining wake behind him;
    one would think the deep had white hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On earth there is nothing like him,
    a creature made without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He beholds all high things;
    he is a king over all the children of pride.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord and said:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that You can do everything,
    and that no thought can be withheld from You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Who is he who hides counsel without knowledge?’
    Therefore I have uttered what I did not understand,
    things too wonderful for me which I did not know.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I have heard of You by the hearing of the ear,
    but now my eye sees You.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I abhor myself,
    and repent in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it was, that after the Lord had spoken these words to Job, the Lord said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath is kindled against you and against your two friends, for you have not spoken of Me what is right as My servant Job has.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, take for yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, and go to My servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and My servant Job will pray for you. For him I will accept, lest I deal with you according to your folly, in that you have not spoken of Me the thing which is right like My servant Job.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the Lord had commanded them; the Lord also accepted Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord restored the fortunes of Job when he prayed for his friends, and also the Lord gave Job twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of his brothers, and all his sisters, and all of those who had been of acquaintance before came to Job, and they ate bread with him in his house, and they consoled him and comforted him for all the adversity that the Lord had brought upon him. Every man also gave him a piece of money and an earring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning, for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand female donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had also seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the name of the first Jemimah; and the name of the second Keziah; and the name of the third Keren-Happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all the land, there were no women as beautiful as the daughters of Job, and their father gave them an inheritance along with their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Job lived a hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and their sons to the fourth generation.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job died, being old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
